subject: Home & DIY
title: How Water Pressure Works
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: How Water Pressure Works.

hook.text: Turn your faucet and water gushes out. But nothing inside your house is pushing it. The pressure comes from far away.

buildup.text: Municipal water towers sit above neighborhoods. Gravity pulling water down through pipes creates steady pressure.

discovery.text: Every 10 meters of elevation adds about 1 bar of pressure. A 30-meter tower gives you roughly 3 barsâ€”plenty for showers.

twist.text: Homes on hills may need booster pumps because gravity works against them. Basements get more pressure than attics.

climax.text: When too many neighbors use water at once, pressure drops. That's why your shower weakens when someone flushes.

punchline.text: A tank on a hill powers every faucet in town.

quiz.question: What primarily creates water pressure in a municipal system?
options: Electric pumps at every street corner
